qas.question: What herbalist wrote about medicinal plants in the 16th century?
Who is considered the father of natural history?
In what plant were cells first discovered by microscope?

context: <a0_0>Physician Valerius Cordus<a0_0/> (1515–1544) authored a botanically and pharmacologically important herbal Historia Plantarum in 1544 and a pharmacopoeia of lasting importance, the Dispensatorium in 1546. Naturalist Conrad von Gesner (1516–1565) and herbalist <a1_0>John Gerard<a1_0/> (1545–c. 1611) published herbals covering the medicinal uses of plants. Naturalist <a2_0>Ulisse Aldrovandi<a2_0/> (1522–1605) was considered the father of natural history, which included the study of plants. In 1665, using an early microscope, Polymath <a3_0>Robert Hooke<a3_0/> discovered cells, a term he coined, in <a4_0>cork<a4_0/>, and a short time later in living plant tissue.
